meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Ex-Governor of Virginia Won't Run for President Mark Warner, the former Virginia governor who spent the past year working to establish himself as the biggest potential rival to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination, said he would not run for the White House. Mr. Warner had drawn interest among party leaders assessing the potential 2008 field both as a centrist Democrat elected in a Southern state and as a wealthy entrepreneur able to finance his own bid.
PAGE A22

Amish Schoolhouse Is Razed The one-room Amish schoolhouse in Lancaster County, Pa., above, where 10 girls were shot last week, five of them fatally, was demolished by heavy machinery in the hope of easing the community's pain.
PAGE A18

Another Baghdad Risk: Trash In Baghdad, where a bomb could be lurking beneath any heap of trash, and insurgents are willing to kill to prevent explosives from being discovered, collecting trash, a low-paying job, has become one of the deadliest occupations.
PAGE A8

Mets Get a Jump on St. Louis The Mets took a 1-0 lead in the National League Championship Series, defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-0, at Shea Stadium. Carlos Beltrán provided the runs with a home run in the sixth inning.
SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1
E. Coli's Source Is Discovered Officials have traced the strain of E. coli in spinach that killed three people and sickened nearly 200 to a California cattle ranch.
PAGE A20

Stocks Rise as Fed Offers Upbeat View of Economy Falling gas prices are leaving Americans with more money to spend, and inflation has become less of a threat in recent weeks, according to a report from the Federal Reserve.

Stock prices surged on the news. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed past 11,900 to close less than 53 points short of 12,000. A separate report showing that the nation's trade deficit reached a record high in August was apparently an afterthought for investors.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

Slain Reporter and Chechnya A Russian newspaper published the last article by its slain correspondent, and transcripts of videotaped torture sessions of Chechens she had obtained, on the same day that a court issued a ruling holding Russia responsible for the executions of five Chechens in 2000.
PAGE A3

Wild Visions on Newsprint ''Master of American Comics'' examines the medium's growth, from early newspaper days to modern self-reflective art. Below, Lyonel Feininger's ''Kin-der-Kids Abroad'' from 1906. A review by Michael Kimmelman.
WEEKEND, PAGE E33
